title: 106_hr5574
content: The "Adoption Does Offer Potential Treasures Act of 2000" and the "Adoption Promotion Act" aim to promote adoption through awareness programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish an adoption awareness program and provide grants to private entities for promoting adoption through public campaigns and distributing materials. To be eligible for a grant under the adoption awareness program, entities must submit an application to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, following specific guidelines and providing necessary information. The Secretary may require information for grants under subsection (a), selected recipients must have favorable recommendations from the Adoption Awareness Commission, and the Federal share of costs is 50 percent. The non-Federal share can be in cash, kind, or services. Establishment of Commission. The Adoption Awareness Commission is established with 7 members appointed by the President, Senate majority and minority leaders, and House Speaker and minority leader. The Adoption Awareness Commission, consisting of 7 members appointed for life, reviews grant applications and public service announcements under section 102. They meet at least 4 times a year to make recommendations to the Secretary. The Adoption Awareness Commission meets at least 4 times a year. Members who are not federal government officers or employees are compensated at a daily rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Officers or employees of the United States serve without additional compensation. Members are allowed travel expenses at authorized rates. The Commission may detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement, procure temporary services at specified rates, and will terminate on September 30, 2005. SEC. 104. Authorization of appropriations for $25,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2005. TITLE II - Adoption credit and exclusion for adoption assistance programs expanded and made permanent under SEC. 201. Increase in maximum benefit to $7,500 ($10,000) and higher income taxpayers now eligible for benefits up to $150,000. Benefits made permanent for all children under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment to section 23(d) of the Internal Revenue Code defines an eligible child as under 18 or incapable of self-care. Section 137 is amended to remove subsection (f) on termination. Section 23 is amended to include a cost-of-living adjustment for adoption dollar limitations after 2001. The adoption credit dollar limitations are increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment, with rounding rules applied for non-multiple amounts. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
